Ah leave me, my flocks, and begone;</br>Far remove from your shepherd and flie!</br>For alas!  he is lost and undone—</br>And alone let him languish and die.</br>I was proud, cruel Phillis averr'd,</br>Too fond of myself e'er to please:</br>And I've hated myself since I heard</br>Such charges imputed as these.

That my modesty was but a cloak</br>The affirm'd imperfection to hide;</br>Affectation she never could brook;</br>And my silence a mark but of pride:</br>On these faults she so charmingly dwelt,</br>Almost I had sworn she was right;</br>None e'er can describe what I felt,</br>The grief that she gave and delight.

But with charges like these do not kill,</br>And do not my silence reprove;</br>Tho' my tongue, yet my eyes were not still,</br>And be sure they were talking of love.</br>Twas diffidence ty'd up my tongue,</br>Admiration of thee held me mute;</br>I forgot both my pipe and my song</br>When I heard thee so sweetly dispute.

None beauty (she said) should e'er prize!</br>I heard her sweet voice and believ'd;</br>But I look'd on her face with surprize,</br>And wonder'd I could be deceiv'd.</br>Not beauty! — then Daphne replied,</br>All hearts should submit to her shrine:</br>Both appealed to me — and I sigh'd—</br>For Phillis and beauty had mine.

I ne'er could dissemble a smile</br>When sorrow corroded my heart,</br>And my tears did not mean to beguile</br>When from Phillis I wept to depart.</br>But ah!  what availeth my love,</br>What avails that I mourn thus and sigh?</br>Phillis ne'er will my passion approve,</br>Altho' with that passion I die.

She still will humility brand</br>With the terms of self-love and of pride;</br>When my pride's to obey her command,</br>And to lay my best gifts by her side:—</br>Of its sweets I would pillage the plain,</br>I would strip the fair grove of its bloom;</br>I would live but her favour to gain,</br>And depend on her smiles for my doom.</br>
